definition: to believe (what sb claims) (usually used in the negative)/(math.) confidence (interval etc)
letter/mail/CL:封[feng1]/to trust/to believe/to profess faith in/truthful/confidence/trust/at will/at random

sentences.english: The shortest Confidence interval of unimodal distribution is discussed.
sentences.chinese: 讨论了单峰分布的最短置信区间的问题。
结果是难以置信的成功。

sentences.english: The latest video games are simply stunning.
sentences.chinese: 最新的视频游戏简直让人难以置信。

sentences.english: It's unbelievable how Jimmy already has a 4 y. o. son.
sentences.chinese: 难以置信的是林志颖已经有了4岁的孩子。

sentences.english: It's also unbelievable to me that he would ever end his life.
sentences.chinese: 对我来说更加难以置信的是他会结束他的生命。

sentences.english: As an argument broke out in Chinese, we felt unbelievably awkward.
sentences.chinese: 一场中国话的争吵爆发时，我们感到难以置信的尴尬。

sentences.english: It is still inconceivably first-rate fun on spruced slopes.
sentences.chinese: 它仍然令人不可置信，一流的山坡上耸立的乐趣。

sentences.english: The total inability to queue and just being generally gormless beyond belief.
sentences.chinese: 没有排队的习惯，而且是难以置信的愚蠢。

sentences.english: Incredible as it seems, live high voltage transmission lines can be worked barehanded.
sentences.chinese: 令人难以置信的，带电高压输电线路可以赤手操作。

sentences.english: It is unbelievable, but I like that.
sentences.chinese: 这很难以置信，但是我喜欢它。

sentences.english: "But they were incredibly inflexible, " she said.
sentences.chinese: “但他们极其不灵活，难以置信，”她说。

sentences.english: Cersei stared at him, uncomprehending. “What woman?
sentences.chinese: 瑟曦难以置信地盯着他，“什么女人？

sentences.english: Ashley laughed in disbelief, and still the presents came.
sentences.chinese: 艾希丽笑了，难以置信，而礼物仍然不断。

sentences.english: That is absolutely the most incredible paper model I have ever seen.
sentences.chinese: 这绝对是最令人难以置信的纸模型我所见过的。

definition: to be shocked/to be appalled/to be terrified
to be surprised/to be amazed/to be stunned
overwhelmed with shock, horror or amazement/dumbstruck/aghast
agape and tongue-tied (idiom); at a loss for words/gaping and speechless
tongue-tied/unable to speak (out of surprise, embarrassment etc)
